content:
18, 2014
												To the Moon always conjures up rather superficial and in my mind nonsensical debate about what constitutes a game and how story-telling should be done within a medium or whether story-telling should even exist in the medium at all. What I've always found odd about this debate is that it's the people who side with the "storytelling in gaming should be done through gameplay, because gaming is its own unique art form and shouldn't just be copying cinema" argument, who are the ones who are being restrictive and limiting the potential of the medium themselves by setting up boundaries and defining what gaming should be.In many ways I hate the term "game". It's a loaded term which tries to specifically narrow down a certain path in which an interactive piece of art/entertainment must go. It also seems to make people's minds up on something before they've even given it a chance and it comes simply from tradition and nothing else. The tradition that video games evolved from more traditional games such as board games and card games, yet has evolved way beyond that. How often have we seen the phrase "it's a good story told in the wrong medium" or "it's not a good game, but a good experience" followed by a mediocre score from he reviewer? I can never understand this - you happily admit the story or the experience affected you emotionally n a positive fashion but because it was in a medium which traditionally, in its formative years 40 or 50 years ago stemmed from traditional games you rate it poorly? Perhaps if To the Moon had been one of the early games which popularised the medium instead of Pong and Space Invaders we wouldn't have this problem.Anyway, I digress. Regardless of history, I find it hard to get my head round why people would want to reduce their own enjoyment of something by creating a narrow definition of something and what can fall into that through nothing but absolute snobbery to even try and prove the medium is an art form (which is another debate in itself) or to argue why certain games are inherently better than others (note: how people who side on this side of the debate re nearly all staunch Valve fans). It certainly does have an impact as well - if people tell themselves cutscenes are inherently bad or interactive fiction is inherently bad they will automatically dislike something in those styles, subconsciously, without ever giving it a chance and therefore reducing their own enjoyment of the medium (which is what I find most perplexing - why would anyone want to do this?) There are even people who claim they would hate their favourite film if it were and minimum level interactive film/FMV game.Perhaps more than a rant about how a game's story should be told though is whether one should be told at all. People accept stories in literature and film because they are tradition, but not al films or literature are about their plots. People don’t enjoy Inland Empire for its plot, they enjoy it for its atmosphere. People don't enjoy Dante's Inferno for its plot, they enjoy it for its atmosphere. There's absolutely nothing which says film or literature or theatre have to be plot based anymore than there is which says gaming can't be, simply because it didn't come from such tradition.Games can be great for an all manner of reasons - some games are great for their great gameplay (Bayonetta), some games are great for their great atmosphere (Silent Hill 2), some games are great for their level design (Deus Ex), some games are great for their rich, intriguing world full of lively characters (Deadly Premonition), some games are great for their pure bizarrity and unpredictability (killer7) and some games ar great or their story (To the Moon). I don't think it takes much or is unreasonable to enjoy all these different things which different games try to achieve. To me decrying To the Moon for its lack of traditional gameplay is no less ridiculous than decrying Tetris for its lack of story or decrying Mario Kart for its lack of atmosphere. You should judge a game on what it tries to achieve. Not because it's some kind of unwritten rule by elitist academia but because it's how you get the most enjoyment out of something and why would anyone want to deny their own enjoyment of something to create some kind of academia superiority? It's irrational. The fact that gaming is so esoteric and has such variety in the things it wants to achieve  from game to game and genre to genre is one of the major reasons I love it so much.And that's assuming that gaming is some kind of inferior medium or storytelling anyway, to which I strongly disagree. It's the interactiveness which make it so suited for storytelling. I think most people will agree that horror games can be genuinely scary even for an experienced horror gamer, whereas after you've reached a certain age and seen a few and become desensitised horror games are not because of their passive nature there is nothing to fear. Whereas in gaming you're controlling the character - It's not just watching passively as someone walks down the hall and seeing h they react when a ghost pops out, it's you controlling that person and you reacting to that ghost popping out. The interactive medium has clear advantages for building atmosphere over the passive medium and it's the same with character bonding. I can’t say I’ve ever cared about a character in a film or television show or play as much as I have plying something like Fire Emblem. That’s because you’ve put the effort it into grow these characters yourself and christ, seeing a character I’ve built up on Fire Emblem die breaks my heart. As hammy as I’m sure that sounds  do think there’s a lot of truth to it and gaming has such advantages that mediums like cinema simply don’t have when it comes to storytelling whereas cinema can do very few things gamin can’t in that respect. In fact, I’d even argue it’s easier for a game to put across emotionally-gripping storytelling simply by the interaction of moving round as it increases your focus and creates the bond and interest in the story through interaction – which no matter how superficial this sounds, is undoubtedly there. And that’s exactly what To the Moon does.	Not to mention people against this kind of interactive fiction - or who claim it should be in a different medium they’re denying thousands of people incredible emotional enjoyment. To the Moon is a game which was made on RPG maker by one person in his bedroom. It cost virtually nothing. There’s absolutely no way this game could ever have been made and had the success it did for virtually nothing if it were a film or a tv show or a play and obviously not have the visual/audio impact it had as a novel. I’d make a tongue-in-cheek reference here about gaming being the “people’s medium” but certainly think indie gaming and things like RPG-maker have allowed people to put forward their ideas for nothing and get success from them, which most other visual mediums cannot.This game made me cry and I don’t just mean my tearducts getting a bit damp and one tear dropping down my face. I mean properly bawl my eyes out til I felt empty in my stomach, cry. Moreso than any piece of art/entertainment in any other medium has as far as I can remember. You can write it off a manipulative or cheesy for attempting this, but the fact it’s been so successful for many people is exactly the point. It’s through its interactievness and your pure focus on the characters and the memories that you wade through throughout the game that the whole thing becomes inescapable and overwhelming. If you go into it with an open-mind rather than trying to meaninglessly  define what gaming should be and instead judge it on what it tries to achieve then it’s an absolutely unreal game and one of the most emotionally rewarding experiences I’ve had in absolutely any artistic medium.

content:
y 12, 2014
												Regret. Indecision. Joy. Sorrow. Indignation. Anger. Helplessness. To The Moon can and will unrelentingly tug at your heartstrings. It will bring you to the fullest extent of each and every single emotion listed, woven together by the most hauntingly beautiful piano music in the background.The graphics, though simple, will form images that will stay in your mind - and heart - for a very long time. The story seems simple but goes to so many complex details as the game unfolds them delicately, just at the right moments. I enjoyed every bit of it, from the tear-inducing plot (so much onions) to the little bits of comic banter, whether in exploring Johnny's world or playing the occasional mini-game.I must concede that the *only* flaw is that there's little replayability value; after all, it is a story-game. But what you get in the 4-5 hours of completing is a wonderful and emotional experience that forces you to look deep inside you. What do you want most in life? What would you pay for it? From thoughts on society and legal obligations, to forced self-reflection on your own goals and dreams, this game has it all.In summary, do I recommend it? I cannot assent more wholeheartedly - it's the first game that affected me so much that I actually just *had* to write this review. I had received this as part of a bundle; but on hindsight, I would have been willing to pay full price. You have to get it on sale, or grab whichever bundle it appears in. Because it's just that good. Add to cart, process, install and grab a good pair of headphones for an amazingly immersive experience.

content:
24, 2016
												Don't judge a game by it's cover. Or in this case, it's engine. You might think that a game made in RPG Maker isn't worth your time. Well, in this case you're wrong. Or at least that depends what you're looking for.'To the Moon' does a lot of things right, but most important and memorable it its writing and atmosphere. Long story short, the game is about exploring a dying man's memories to grant him a final wish. What you get is an emotional ride with both ups and downs, mostly the latter. But the game is all about its story and it's perfectly executed.But if you're looking for an RPG, you're looking in the wrong place. The game has no sort of choice-and-consequence system, no fighting (except for one battle, but I won't spoil that!) or nothing that would make this rank as an RPG. The game will always be the same, so there's not much replay value to it.So if you're looking for a game with a great story to invest a few hours into, look no further. Freebird Games will prove to you that you don't need to be a AAA-studio to make an enjoyable and memorable gaming experience.

0, 2013
												Simply put, this game is the most beautiful indie game experience I've ever had.  Words cannot describe the powerful feelings this game evoked within me. The story is from the perspective of two doctors. These doctors possess a device that allow them to traverse the very memories of a person. They can manipulate those memories to make the patients dying wish come true. It is a five hour journey, but one many should take. It allows you insight on a condition certain people have to live with throughout their lives, as well as the bonds between two souls and how tragedy and circumstance cannot make them falter.   I cried so hard. I was crying because of the beauty of the message and the happiness of the finale, but also the emanating sadness of the whole story. When you go to the moon you will feel joy, sorrow,  and compassion.

content:
ry 4, 2013
												Full disclosure: this isn't as much of a "game" as it is an interactive story; think Ace Attorney or Analogue: A Hate Story. Or Final Fantasy IV. (ZING) So while there are a few mini-games, To The Moon doesn't require your senses of strategy or customization like the 90's-era JRPG's it's designed in the style of. What is DOES require is simply four continuous hours and a box of tissues.To The Moon has a beautifully crafted story. Look no further if you're looking from something that can switch to heartfelt to depressing to shocking to laugh-out-loud hilarious at the drop of a hat. Or several hats, rather.And the story is greatly helped by the fact that the writing is excellent. From John & River's love story told in reverse, to the banter between Doctors Watts & Rosalene, everything simply feels natural. The subtle references to Doctor Who and How I Met Your Mother are the icing on the cake.I was going to put something else - largely to wrap this up - but whatever. Just go play it. (I was serious about the "four continuous hours" thing, though. This is the type of game that's meant to be played in one sitting.)Oh, and the music is great too.

content:
er 26, 2015
To the Moon is a heart-rending tale of dreams, memories, and knowing that love is malleable, capable of taking forms of true beauty, when worked by the right soul. It is my firm belief that you would enjoy To the Moon, so let me sell you further.Part 1: The StoryThe story starts off with two scientist-type fellows known as Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene, employees of a mysterious corporation known as Sigmund Corp. They are specifically tasked with providing the elderly and sick with fulfilling lives before they die, by using the means of a certain memory-altering dream machine that allows them to rewrite their client's memory to fit their ordered specifications. Their client, an old, withering man known only by the name Johnny, has enlisted the help of these two scientists. His request, to become an astronaut and fly high into the sky, to reach the outer edge of the world and engage in a long-awaited rendezvous with the moon. Things go routine for a good while, until it appears that something is very wrong with Johnny's memory. Segmented and heavily disjointed, the mind of the elderly man seems to only connect via a single thread, memories of his deceased wife, River. You'll find along the way that she holds major significance to Johnny, much more than could be originally thought, but I'll leave the satisfaction to you.Part 2: GameplaySurely no game is great without some equally complementing gameplay. Whilst travelling through this cavalcade of emotions and memories, you'll have to deal with searching the man's memories and finding items that can link each piece together, like a grand cranium jigsaw puzzle. Mementos will be scattered about for you to interact and find, and engaging in absorbing the story from each memory is a must if you are to succeed. You'll have to go through some light puzzle elements in order to gain access to the linking power of the mementos, but it's nothing a little brain power can't fix. And even with all this brainiac gameplay, there are indeed moments of action. Remember that squirrel you narrowly dodged on the road? Well, I won't say much, but I can say that you surely haven't seen the last of him. You'll need to have a fighter's spirit, but keeping a shoe handy is about the same.Part 3: The LessonThe game holds with it not only what you can gather from surface value, but it also carries underneath it a plethora of teachings and meanings. Now nothing I say here is set in stone, as you take what you will from the experience, but what I've collected from the game is as follows: One of the hardest things to do is to do nothing at all, that sometimes love will find us no matter where we are, and that strangers we meet can be the most interesting people we will ever get to know. These certainly aren't the only lessons to be drawn from this wonderful game, interpretation is a most beautiful thing. I leave the gorgeously complex teachings of this game to you to find, as making your own connections is supremely satisfying, and I'd be nobody to deny you the pleasure.OverviewThis game is definitely worth the priced listed. A fine game with charming graphics, a beautiful story, and a heart-rending conclusion that will leave you fully satisfied with your purchase. With the characters very fleshed out and unique, alongside the "worlds" you'd be visiting, not to mention the beautiful OST that'll be accompanying you, I'd give it a most well-deserved 9/10. Buy this game, love this game, remember this game.

content:
9, 2014
												To The Moon is simply one of the best story based games ive played in my entire life.A game that went under the radar for many people, developed by a small studio called Freebird Games, To The Moon is an incredible and heart breaking experience, as it will bring the manliest of men to there knees in tears.In short, its about 2 Doctors traveling through the memories of a dying man to fulfill his final wish, there isnt too much I can give away without ruining some part of the story, so hear this, play this game, buy it and play it, this game is simply incredible.This game was an emotional rollercoaster for me and many others who played this game, as you tie bits and pieces of the story together as you progress, you feel youself becoming weaker and more emotional as realisation sets in and you learn how sad the life of this old man really is.The game consists only of clicking around with your mouse, as there is no action, no fighting and no enemies to face, this may seem as a turn off for many, but in reality it is just a better way to immerse yourself in the game and its story, it simply couldnt be represented in a better way.From the outstanding soundtrack, spectacular story and the brilliant dialogue that this game delivers, its simply a masterpiece, and all that in around 3-4 hours of gameplay.9/10I can see why many people will and have enjoyed this game, but can also see why others may not.

content:
9, 2015
 To The Moon  is a truly beautiful game. It's very essence screams with emotion and you find yourself screaming with it. This game is the kind of game you sit down expecting to try for half an hour at 11:00 at night and find yourself still playing sometime the next morning. It's story proves engaging and litterally enthralls you as you become the game's minion. Entrusting you with simple tasks,  To The Moon  requires one to search in reverse chronological order small memories of a dying man in an attempt to convince a younger reflection of himself to follow a certain path in life, motivating him to fulfill his own death wish. As should be plain as daylight, untrained professionals such as us are provided with every opprotunity by Freebird Games to come in conact, learn about, and fall in love with the characters as we travel backwards through a man's most intimate and poignant moments of living. You spend hours caught up in this man's life, almost understanding him as well as he does himself, and that's where you find you've actually spent hours getting caught up in a magnificent and chancy trap: You slowly realize it as the story progresses, I will not reaveal it here, but you do inwardly question this dying man as you roam his thoughts. It even talks about a topic that is not quite well addressed in media and especially in games, and that is commendable in and of itself. Mental illnesses require the attention of close loved ones. This game explores the "whens" and "wheres" of unconditional love and just how significant it is in the lives of others. The entire time you are investing in a one-way friendship with this man, you are accompanied by a moving, extremely well crafted soundtrack he soundtrack is so fantastic it makes one wish they could either play, pick up again, or practice these songs on the piano. A mix between simplicity and complexity that complements the story line and the artstyle; everything comes together so thoroughly. If one were looking only for music, this game shines as brightly as any lighthouse. Now, in a sea of drama, the pair of scientists one guides through the memories provide comedic relief and this is where I could see where we lost a portion of the (at the time of writing) 440 out of 16010 people who did not recomend this game and that number could have been cut if there had been the following warning: the characters you play will bicker like siblings and they are present to cut tension. If they were not there, the story would be too heavy to handle. I enjoyed their presence and I laughed out loud a number of times as they allowed the developers over at Freebird to show their humor in a creative way. Actually, I find them reminiscent of certain characters Shakespeare would include in his works (i.e. the Porter in Macbeth) in order to plant some kind of restraint in an otherwise constant flow of deep and taxing storytelling. Please do not let yourself be unwilling to play this game because of them. My only personal complaint are the controls. I will say that this game is a point and click interactive story that one should use the arrow keys and enter/space bar for. I found the point and click clunky and not always accurate. I lost nothing in using the arrow keys, though, so it does work. Also, I found there to be too much delay in the memento puzzles for the amount of computing it should take. That did not detract much either as I was too busy figuring out moves anyway. That's it. The end of my complaints. "Use the arrow keys and I thought they could have cleaned up the programming for the puzzles. Otherwise, job well done. Fantastic story. Fantatstic sound track. Interesting art. 15571/16011 would play again." Thank you for your time.

content:
y 8, 2014
												To the Moon is one of the most touching games I've played in years. With such a wonderfully written storyline riddled with humerous and nostalgic references alike, TtM really shines with it's interpretation of memories. When I played the first few moments I expected an interesting Sci-Fi interpretation of how the mind works, which was delivered promptly, but I hadn't expected how utterly mind-blowing of a level it would reveal itself to land on. Flawlessly implementing emotional story-telling, point-and-click gameplay, and an ocean of character progression, TtM leaves you on the edge of your seat, yearning for the next act of the three installments. I haven't felt the pressure of tears behind my eyes as a result from a game since Kingdom Hearts and Shadow of the Colossus were released in 2002 and 2005 respectively. Had this game been released during my preadolescence, it would've been just as impacting on my development as those two games were. In all honesty, even at this stage of my life, I found this game to be rather impacting, as well as eye opening on many levels.To the Moon is a game I'd recommend for all ages, as a casual point-and-click story driven adventure RPG, it has so much to offer to every generation. Undoubtedly worth the extra 'dough' for the heart-string-pulling soundtrack as well, especially considering that 50% of the bandcamp proceeds go towards charities.10/10, will play again.

content:
7, 2014
												This game is just brilliant. It is inspiring, humorous, suspensful, and just full of heart...I finished To The Moon in one sitting. I tried to pull away, but I just couldn't help myself. I cried, I laughed, and felt so much emotion while playing this simply beautiful game... Dr. Neil Watts was my favorite character. He was seriously funny, sarcastic, but not all he appears to be- for a while, he looks to be quite disinterested and just looking for the next joke, but near the end of the game he shocks you with how much he cares about people's happiness. He really was a fantastic character that I can't wait to see more of in the next installment.Johnny... Oh boy. The way the game played through his life backwards just made it more painful. All that he went through... just wow. When you see all of his hopes and dreams when he was young, but seeing that it didn't turn out.. it's really hard. And you just grow unspeakably attached to him, forgetting that these are only memories and he's really fading away on a death bead. This game was just unbelieveable. I adored everything, from the plot to characters , the gameplay to the entertaining puzzles, and of course- the soundtrack. I suggest you buy the collecter edition with the Soundtrack. It's quite worth the 2 dollars extra.I recommend this to anyone who is looking for a beautiful game that will make you question what, and who, you spend your life with, and make you appreciate the simplest things that you have.

content:
er 30, 2015
												"I'm too manly for this." -Dr. Neil WattsI usually don't write reviews, but for this game I feel like I must. (Sorry for my English, not my main language)My story is that I was searching for games with easy 100% achievements (Yeah, I'm sort of an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥) and I found this game... Boy, what a game. It had almost everything: The visuals were appealing, the characters were pretty nice, and I got really interested in their stories, the story progression is fantastic, I literally didn't see some of the stuff coming, regarding the events that lead up to the ending which was a little bit predictable and the soundtrack is spot on. A little something that not everyone is a fan of has to be the lack of action; this is a "Point and Click" game, so it may not have the best gameplay in the world, heck, even I found it a little bit grindy or boring in the first half hour, but I'm getting used to that since I've been playing more games like that lately. But in my opinion, the things mentioned before makes up for it. The game is a little bit short, but the feels stay...In conclusion, I'd say this game is completely worth your money, and it's even better on a sale, it gets pretty well discounted. I rate it 5 jars of olives out of 5 jars of olives

content:
y 29, 2014
												This is not a game. It's an interactive story where clicking is required to progress from scene to scene and from dialog to dialog.  The fact that from times to times some ridiculously easy puzzles have to be solved in order to progress doesn't exactly make it a game. There's nothing challenging about it.Anyway, its best part is the story. It's a complex story that treats matters of life and death in such way that it gets to be felt quite close and personal. I completely don't recommend this to depressive people. I was on the verge of busting into tears several times throughout its duration. The story is great, very touching and impactful. It's hard to speak about it without spoiling it, but I guess I could say it somehow reminds of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, the movie, but only in just a few aspects.Other than the story (but damn, what a story!...), there was nothing I liked about how "To the moon" presented itself to me. The soundtrack supports the story pretty well, it enhances the feelings that the story transmits, but it gets cheesy at points, near the end. Don't get me wrong, it's an awesome soundtrack that clearly shows the loads of work it required, but it's just not my type, I'm more into the Bastion-like soundtracks.Many people seem to have found the strength to tolerate the awful graphics, but I still can't ignore them. It's an "RPG Maker"-like, uber low budget kind of graphics that ruined for me the immersiveness of the "to the moon" experience at points. Since the clicking and controlling was also quite imprecise, I think I would've even prefered a slideshow of still images instead of some of the scenes where just moving around was pretty annoying and tedious. It also lacks basic settings like sound volume controls, full screen / window mode toggling, screen resolution settings, all the basic stuff. At least it comes with steam cloud support and a pretty neat, single "Steam achievement".Anyway, I don't regret the money spent on it and the 3 hours and a half that it took me to finish it. It's a great experience. It's also, indeed, worthy of still being considered the saddest game of all. I submit to this general opinion as well.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2013
												What do you do when you want to tell an immersive story via the medium of computer games, but you don't know how to program?Kan Gao decided that that was no problem at all and just used RPGMaker. That explains the retro JRPG look of "To the Moon", which (WARNING!) is not actually a game. It's really more of an interactive story (and a rather short one at that, with 3 - 5 hours of play time)."To the Moon" is set 20 minutes into the future where it is possible to change dying people's memories so that they can make the things "happen" that they wish they had done in their lifetime.The technicians Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts make these wishes come true. Their latest client, Johnny, has a peculiar goal: He wants to go to the moon. He cannot remember where this desire came from, but he definitely wants to go.As the technicians dive into Johnny's memories, more and more questions arise and mysteries need to be unravelled. I'd rather not spoil the plot to you by telling more - discovering things and figuring out the answers from the clues presented is half the enjoyment here.When I first noticed that this was not a "real" game some way into "To the Moon", it annoyed me a bit since it had not been said on the box. What won me back is that the story we're told is quite touching and rewarding. I dare you to not care about Johnny, Eva and Neil by the end of events! To keep everything in memory (and for ultimate impact on "the feels"), it's best played in one sitting, like, say, one rainy afternoon. And do keep a box of tissues and a bottle of water close by, you might need them.(Also, the music is fantastic. The whole soundtrack can be found on Bandcamp under http://freebirdgames.bandcamp.com/album/to-the-moon-ost - give the main theme a try.)

content:
ry 9, 2015
												Beautiful, emotional storytelling. It's a story first, and a point and click game second. The game is simply the medium. It's funny, serious, dark and hopeful all at once. A simple concept experienced masterfully, games don't normally affect me but this one struck a chord. The soundtrack is only a couple of very basic tracks, but it is hauntingly beautiful, and deserving of the pickup. In many ways, this game is like a movie experience with the added benefit of your own input and interaction. Visually, it's retro look gives it charm, and it's impressive how much emotion can be conveyed with pixelated animation. You take the role of a pair of specialists who enter peoples memories, specifically dying people, to generate an experience from them that they express as a dying wish. In a style reminiscent of Inception they dive into the life of John, to fulfill his wish to go To The Moon. They have great chemistry, with fantastic pop culture references and lots of one liners. The story they discover is touched with meaning and emotion. I can't say what makes this game so great without revealing anything that happens, but it brought me to bittersweet tears.I bought this on a whim, a whim I now very greatful for. It's a truly enriching game, and it will make you cry.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2014
												It's hard to describe how much I love To the Moon. I say love, and not "loved" because it's one of those games that will stick with me forever. I've never experienced a game that made me feel so sentimental. While it doesn't have much as far as gameplay is concerned, To the Moon more than makes up for it in its intriguing and heartfelt narrative. It intertwines humor and heartfelt drama under a veil of mystery--keeping the player hooked from start to finish. I'm amazed at what this game achieves. If you're looking for in-depth gameplay and top-notch graphics then this probably isn't what you're looking for. However, if you enjoy great storytelling, character development and a soundtrack worth buying and listening to hours after the game ends, then you've come to the right place. Though it's rather short, I loved every second of it and still do not regret spending the money on it. This is the only game I've played on Steam I would urge buying at full price. This is because the creator needs money to support his art of game-making, and seriously, the guy is good.

content:
11, 2014
												To the Moon is a indie adventure game designed and built in RPG Maker, though it is not actually an RPG in the traditional  sense it looks as if it is, though there is no combat (Except as a joke in one spot) and very little actual gameplay outside of the usual adventure game mechanics of talking to everyone and finding things in the environment.In To the Moon you play as two doctors who are employed by the Sigmund Corporation under a new wish fulfillment service that people may use as they are dying, it lets the doctors alter memories to help someone believe they fulfilled their life long dream, and as such they are called to the house of Johnny Wyles who's dying wish is to go to the moon, but he does not know why, so as the two doctors you must go through Johnny's memories and figure out why while also building things up for Johnny to become an astronaut.Now... I am leaving out key parts to the story here because I do not wish to spoil it but suffice it to say To the Moon may have one of the best stories I have ever come into contact with in a video game, it is beautifully written to the point that I was in tears multiple times while playing it, despite how it looks graphically the writing shines through and delivers powerful emotions that tug at your heartstrings.Although it may seem a bit short, clocking in at about four to five hours long, less if you know exactly what to do, it is well worth it, an amazing experience from top to bottom, polished with very little flaws outside of repeating the same sliding puzzle every time you jump memories.And on a side note the soundtrack is totally worth it, the musical score is memorable to the point that after you finish the game, even just the music will bring back memories of the story, all in all a must play for anyone who cares about an amazing story in a video game.

content:
2014
												This game deserves nothing below a 9, that's the lowest that you can go for a game like this. This game is so well formed, the plot, the characters, how they develop and connect. Given the aesthetic setting, you might assume it's a silly indie game or something that might touch upon deeper emotions and matters without actually going the whole way, deeper and exploring the story completely. However the writers for this game clearly worked very hard on this, with so many connections that it's only up the the player's intellect to actually connect them and evaluate them on a personal level. This game does not force you to do anything, it plays smoothly without anything for the player to worry about missing. Just playthrough and enjoy the game. And if you've paid enough attention, then deeper meaning will be revealed and the greater your appreciation will be for the writing. The game has a few interesting and entertaining moments of comic relief (and believe me, you will need them) and fun cultural references. The timing, presentation and music really manage to hit the right chords.This is a genuinely good game, suitable for everyone to enjoy. Each person will have a slightly different experience but even if you've understood the absolute minimum, it's still a grand game worth remembering when comparing to other future contenders who dare set foot in this very challenging genre.

content:
2, 2015
A Paladin’s Steam Review: To The Moon. A Lot of Feels Story, not a Lot of Gameplay.Genre: Sci-Fi Adventure Comedy/Tragedy Story Driven Experience. Developed & Published by: Freebird GamesPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux.Business Model: Base GameCopy Purchased by Myself Overall Story Thoughts & Gameplay MechanicsThe story is about two doctors who provide a service to people on their deathbeds. This service they perform is where they go into the person’s memories and change events in their head so that it concludes how they would prefer. The game is focused on one such patient and uncovering pieces of his past. There’s some interesting subjects brought up in the game, about life and death. About the moral and philosophical questions brought up about what these two are doing and the actions with regards to the patient. That being said, I feel like this is a game best experienced by yourself. It's not a story I really want to get into or dissect, as I feel that takes away from the experience. I won't deny that this is a bit of a cop-out but at the same time, that's why I don't usually cover titles like To the Moon all that often. I find them difficult to cover. The gameplay amounts to you finding certain important items on the level and advancing the story along. There’s not a lot that you, the player, can do when it comes to this game. A lot of the game expects to be watched and read, so there’s not much variance to the experience worth nothing. I get that narrative-driven games are like this, but, it’s getting more and more tiresome. PC SettingsSettings for this game are extremely lacking. No resolution options (it runs in a 640x480 resolution), v-sync option is hidden away in the game properties menu which is only accessible by pressing F1 in-game (not something that’s made immediately clear I might add). Keybindings can be changed for both controller and mouse + keyboard though. There are separate volume sliders as well. The graphics are a 2D pixelated affair, with a top-down jRPG-like camera angle. Music is an instrumental affair with a lot of solo piano and strings. It works well to create a morose sort of weight to the game. Side note: the free DLC story that comes with To the Moon doesn't play on anything but Windows. It's ok, a nice little freebie. Final ThoughtsTo the Moon is pretty good. The story certainly has its feels and the game is laser focused on telling a tight story. I’ll give them credit that despite being a passive observer for the majority of it, they clearly knew what they wanted to tell. It’s not an entirely passive affair but the most you’ll end up doing is finding items to advance the plot along, moving around rooms and talking with people. There’s some interesting philosophical and ethical questions about death that are brought up as well. Other than that, what’s left to say...Read the review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
23, 2013
												To the Moon is not really a game, but more like... interactive fiction. The two Docs are helping this old man who said he wanted to go to the moon, but he can't remember why. By going back in his memory and hopefully by stitching it back together in a certain way, they can reweave the memory to allow the mind to fill in the details, thus allowing the patient to die with a sense of fulfillment rather than regret. Except the Doctors have met their match... as there are some secrets that this man is hiding... and they must search through the catacombs of his memories to locate the clues... Don't let the cute 2D graphics that resemble Japanese console RPG turn you off. This game is MUCH deeper than that. They simply chose to spend the developement time on the story rather than hiring artists to do bazillion illustrations. At its heart, its a love story, about broken promises, unfilfilled wishes and potentials, and about taking chances, and how one encounter can change a life. It is a short game, and you should have no problem finishing it in a few hours. And you may be shedding a few tears at the end.

The elements that have pretensions to being gameplay are linear in the extreme, and very simple to "solve".Do not mistake the lack of gameplay for a lack of merit. To The Moon is an excellent work, which I wholeheartedly recommend. The particulars might not fall into everyone's tastes, but the concept and execution are sufficiently good that it at least deserves a try.Still. There are a few notable flaws. Firstly, the pretensions to gameplay can be mildly distracting, more so the less adept one is at solving the minor puzzles. Secondly, certain parts of the dialogue are highly - and needlessly - intertextually referential, despite this intertextuality having almost no real merit for the larger narrative. Thirdly, the basic point-and-click system used for most of the game is clunky, and may disrupt the pacing of the narrative.A sincere recommendation of an excellent - but not masterful - work.

content:
ber 16, 2015
												To be clear, this game has a pretty small amount of classic gameplay. You explore and experience a story. It's not walking-simulator tier, but it's entirely focused on the story it wishes to tell, rather than the gameplay aspect.However, the story itself is awesome. Such a great way to spend around four hours. Few places can you get such a concise and well delivered story, with a strong soundtrack to back its heart. You will find yourself able to recall songs in the soundtrack even after only playing for around four hours, that's a very good thing. Memorable and enjoyable soundtracks are something I love in games.Extremely well worth the money. This gives you so much more than watching a great movie, while costing a fraction of the price. Characters are well developed and each have their own personality that are enjoyable to watch. I'm pre-emptively trying to find the sequel that has just been announced so I can wishlist it. There's an overarching storyline that connects the two main scientists to the next game, as they work on multiple "patients", this game covers a single patient's story. So in future sequels, we'll get to see a continuation of the development of these characters. I just love that! You don't see direct connections like that often.Only gripes are that the sprite grid is a bit too large, like your position is very here-or-there, you can't always position yourself exactly where you want to be easily. Also, in a couple of places I have to switch from using a controller to a mouse because the controller wasn't able to do what I was required to do. Should support all control schemes (especially in simple setups.)Definitely recommended. A character-focused adventure that just about anyone can relate to and enjoy.

content:
ry 16, 2015
 Beautiful. Before going in-depth with my review for the game, I want to sum it up with that one word alone:  Beautiful.Upon purchasing the game, I didn't know what I was getting myself into. Sure, I've heard praises about it some time ago and it was on sale recently for a very reasonable price. So, I bought the game along with its soundtrack bundled in without any idea what to truly expect. And after just finishing the game recently, I can safely say that what I got was an experience worth every penny. Keyword: "experience".I'll start off by discussing what I think is the main problem that people seem to have for the game (based on the negative Steam reviews).This game is labeled as an "Indie Adventure Role Playing Game". It was also designed through the RPG Maker XP engine. So it is of no surprise that people expect at least a bit of RPG Maker gameplay elements that are typically found elsewhere. But this game doesn't have that. In fact, aside from very simple puzzles, this game doesn't have much else in terms of 'gameplay'. And therein lies the problem. It's hard to call it a 'game' when it barely has any gameplay elements to it. Heck, as long as you keep playing there's no way to lose the game. It's more like a movie with a few interactions added here and there. I personally expected a bit of a challenge too but the game was too easy and too linear. But is that necessarily a bad thing?No. In my opinion, it's not.In fact, because of how straightforward the gameplay is, I was able to progress through the story very quickly in anticipation for what's going to happen next. All I had to do was overcome a bit of a hurdle in order to progress through the story and it didn't bother me at all.That is why I prefer calling it an 'experience' as opposed to calling it a 'game'. It is a  story-driven experience. The lack of any complicated gameplay made all the other aspects of the game shine.The graphics may be your typical RPG Maker stuff, but it's better-looking than most of the games made through the RPG Maker engine. The story...well, without spoiling much let's just say that there are a lot of feels found in this game. One minute I'm laughing at the interactions between the two main characters, and the next minute I'm trying my best to hold back my tears from too much feels (and most of the time failing to hold back said tears; no shame in that). And the music? Oh man, the music...the music in this game is arguably its greatest asset. The music found in the game is very beautiful. Each soundtrack served its purpose in making every scene of the game much more enjoyable and memorable. If you buy the game, I implore you to buy the soundtrack as well. It's worth it.It's a short game; only took me around 4 hours to finish. But every second of that 4 hours was worth it. It was a short but sweet ride.I highly recommend this game.

ry 6, 2014
												To The Moon, with no doubt one of the best SP experience on PC Gamer life, and we need to congratulate Freebird Games for making a good game on RPG Maker. Contains simple animations but good, good lighting and awesome OST. However this game lacks in one thing for me - but inst very important though - the gameplay, it has some bugs like, get stuck on tree, start flying in mid game its not very important but a bit annoying. Also don't expect lot of action in To The Moon. Talking about To The Moon, on this game we control 2 characters, Drº Neil and Drª Eva that both work on company called  "Sigmund Agency of Life Generation", and the goal of that company is to grant people with low prospect of living. Now through a machine, Drº Neil and Drª Eva, step into people memory and change them and help they fulfill their wishes. By the game name, To The Moon, we can see what would be the wish they would make. John - main character - wants to go the moon and they will help him. Now when we are traveling through  John memories we need to pick up some objects to link some memories.In perfect game we need a perfect OST, and guess what? We have a extremely good one! Sometimes i would left the game ruining on backgroud just to hear the awesome OST. Now you want a game with good story? Excellent OST? Great story lines? Pick this up! ~ 9/10

But yeah, I think most people will enjoy it.

												What can I say? When I first booted up To the Moon I was expecting an RPG in the likes of final fantasy (based on the graphics). Instead what I got was a gripping and emotional rollercoaster ride filled with joy, love and loss. The characters have realistic personalities and funny at times which makes it easier to connect to them. The soundtrack is superb and does a marvelous job of setting the mood during gameplay. Story is the main attraction here, taking elements from Pixar's 'UP' as inspiration for the mature themes presented. The only fault is the gameplay, which involves moving around and doing simple puzzles. However since the focus of this game isn't the gameplay, it's not a major  issue (it's more like an interactive visual novel).I highly recommend everyone to play this game or at least have a go. It's a story you won't forget.

content:
er 19, 2014
												SPOILER-FREE REVIEW!In over four decades of playing video games, only a handful have ever elicited strong emotional responses with me. "Final Fantasy VII," "Ico," "Shadow of the Colossus," and "Journey" are among the very few that have had such a powerful effect. "To The Moon" can now take its rightful place alongside those titles. From beginning to end, I never once turned it off or took a break. It had me hooked in from the very moment I turned it on, and it is still haunts me even after its overwhelming finale. This will be a game that I shall remember many, many years from now. There are so many moments that brought me to tears, probably more than any other game, and I loved it. If you are not touched by the game's beautiful story, you have no heart. By the game's conclusion, you will wonder to yourself if your life would have been better had you taken different paths at different times in your past. If given the opportunity to change it, would you?Graphics: 10/10 - The character design, rich colors, backgrounds, and little details made me feel like I was in this world.Sound: 7/10 - There's not much, but what's there is perfectly suited for this game. The heart beats and distorted laughs are memorable.Music: 10/10 - Every track is flawless.Gameplay: 7/10 - Mostly walking around and touching objects. The puzzles are not challenging, but the product's more of an interactive story than a game. Some people could be put off by its simplicity.Story: 10/10 - You WILL cry.Overall: 10/10 - One of the best games I've played in years. Freebird Games proves that you don't need huge budgets, realistic graphics, buckets of blood, or name brand recognition to produce a great game -- and this truly is a GREAT game.There is no excuse; you must play this game before you die. You won't regret it.

There is no voice acting, which is a shame, but the music adds atmosphere, and there is something quaint about the simplicity of it, and the ability to tell such a good story through this medium. I'd recommend this game, especially to women who know who Tony Attwood or Rudy Simone are.

content:
3, 2016
Product received for free
To the moon is a point and click RPG which has a fantastic story and great music. There is no battle system in the game and your entire playthrough (6 hrs average) will be story driven. The following are my views and feelings about the game after a single playthrough. I will not be discussing the story to avoid giving spoilers but will say that the story, nay, entire playing experience was absolutely wonderful. Positives:- The story gets really interesting early on and the experience goes only uphill from there.- The characters and their dialouges are very well written and unique.- The game has great flow and pacing.- The "Time travelling" mechanic, especially solving memento puzzles was fun and added to the story.- The Music is the strongest point of the game imo. 10/10 if I would rate it.- The humor is great and jokes are plenty. I mostly had a grin on my face. - I like how the game was not very difficult which at least made my playthrough enjoyable.- The game also makes one feel a mix of emotions including feeling weird at times, which was good.- There were several neat refrences like animorphs books etc.- The graphics are standard RPG style and the controls are simple/easy.Negatives:- I could not play the game on my gaming laptop as it would not run even after following instructions by the developers. I do know that many players have had the same problems which started during the steam summer sale (2016). I played the game on my brother's laptop and it ran most of the time.- I changed the DEP settings on my laptop but I kept getting "Script is hanging" error and critical errors afterwards.  Final thoughts: To the Moon is an excellent RPG with a great story and an even greater soundtrack. I had a blast playing the game. I would recommend this game just for the soundtrack alone but luckily it has a touching story and well written characters which makes it a must have if you like RPGs.  9.5/10Extra: best joke from the game imo :DJohnny: What are you reading?    River: ...A book.I received this game for review purposes from Steamified. All these reviews are unsponsored, unsolicited meaning that I am not entitled to favor all reviews with either a positive or negative score for any games I am sent for review. This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

content:
y 1, 2015
												The Bad:-The graphics are pretty terrible.-There is no real gameplay apart from a few very easy puzzles and your basic explore-and-interact. The Good:+The soundtrack is beautiful and used very well throughout the story.+The story is very well written and extremely emotional. Every detail throughout the game is well planned, every mystery has a great payoff, it all connects brilliantly and the dialogue (Text only, no voice acting) is really good.Overall, you play as 2 scientists who alter dying people's memories to fulfill a wish for them (or, at least, make them believe it came true). In this case, they're out to help an old man called John H. Wyles, who's dying wish is to go (you guessed it) to the moon. What makes this case a bit different to their normal ones is that Johnny hasn't the faintest idea as to why he even wants that. He just knows he does. The game's divided into 3 acts. The first one is mostly about establishing the backstory and leanring about Johnny's life. It's pretty slow paced, and mostly sets up questions to be answered later. The 2nd act picks up the pace, and from there till the end I found the game hard to stop playing.It takes a bit over 3 hours to finish, so I recommend finishing it in 1 sitting for maximum impact.

content:
1, 2013
												I purchased To the Moon on a whim because it had strong reviews and was on sale. Plus, the game description intrigued me, and I thought if nothing else, it might be a decent way to spend the evening.Four hours later, and I am crying harder than I have in months. I honestly don't know how to describe this game without spoiling the magic of it. This is one of the titles I will point to when people contend that video games cannot be art. They absolutely can be, and this indie might well be considered a masterpiece. The story of To the Moon is tragic, beautiful, and sad. It is often funny and sometimes hilarious. It is the first video game that ever stirred my emotions to the point of tears. And it gave me a newfound appreciation for life. Seriously.Some details would probably be helpful. You play as Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts, two specialists who are hired to modify clients' memories so that the last thing they remember on their deathbeds is the fulfillment of a grand and final wish. This is achieved by working backwards through the patient's remembered life, planting the seed of an idea in their early childhood so that their new, artificial life will play out the way it needs to in order for the wish to take hold. Their latest job is an old man named Johnny, a widower who wants to go to the moon. Only thing is, he doesn't remember why he wants to go, only that he must. So our heroes set up their equipment, enter his most recent memory, and start seeing the man's life in reverse.What begins as a standard point-and-click title quickly weaves into a heartbreaking and simultaneously joyous exploration of life, death, love and its flaws, dreams and the crushing feeling of losing them, promises kept and broken, the future, the past, and the importance of making the present count. It portrayed the shattering realities of illness, financial woes, selfishness, and failure. It captured the grief of not understanding someone you love and the tragedies that befall all of us. It illustrates how love is powerful but also incredibly painful and complex. It makes you think about how each one of us is the hero of our own story, and how much it hurts when we don't live up to the title. It makes you think about how we take so many things and people for granted, and the peculiarities of what does and doesn't stick in our memory. It shows us the importance and the absurdity of chasing after nostalgia, of knowing that something in your possession matters but not remembering why. It shows how easy it is to see other people's mistakes in life while ignoring our own. It pointed out how we would rather act than listen. To the Moon made me think about my own real-life relationships and how I could (should) put more effort into them. It made me think about dozens of chance encounters I've had, the dreaded "What if?" It made me smile with its true-to-life depictions of talking to girls, arguing with co-workers, and gently mocking one's friends. And it emotionally wrecked me with its dramatic twists, gorgeous soundtrack, and perfect ending. It's like someone took the first 10 minutes of the Pixar film UP, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, and several classic RPGs and threw them in a blender.Some of the dialogue and the mental images that followed it made me think of other, bigger titles, such as Bioshock Infinite. Oh, how we love our lighthouses... But the story here is much more intimate and private, like reading a journal that someone's kept since they were 5. The visuals are charming, going for an old-school RPG look like Link to the Past or the original Harvest Moon. Cinema was obviously a huge influence on some of the particulars, notably Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and Inception. Still, this is a truly original work, one that will stick in your brain long after it ends. The story's ability to make you cry, laugh (sometimes at once), and reflect is something few video games can do. It's something few movies or books can do. Get To the Moon, and let yourself be affected.Edit: I've nominated To the Moon for the "I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye" Award. There is no other possible contender. Play this already.

er 30, 2014
												Wow. I played this all in one sitting. Start to finish. Absolutely brilliant. Could not put it down. It's like if someone took Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind and combined it with Inception to a create a story about doctors who dive into the memories of the dying to artificially fulfill their dying wish by creatively revising their memories (emphasis on Eternal Sunshine). I was initially (and perhaps unfairly) skeptical of what a story could do with pixel art, but am happy to say I was quite wrong. This was much, much better than I expected. I appreciated all the subtle but extremely significant connections that go completely unmentioned, providing deep rewards for the more perceptive and analytical story-focused players. The story also does beautiful things with an autism spectrum character that left me very impressed. A++ more please.

content:
er 16, 2013
												It is extremely rare to find a work of art as brilliant as To the Moon. This visual novel revolves around Johnny Wyles, a dying man who has lived a sad, and unfulfilling life. Johnny's dying wish is to go to the moon, though he doesn't know why. To make this wish a reality, he enlists Dr. Eva Rosaline and Dr. Neil Watts of Sigmund Corp. who are determined to send Johnny to the moon one way or another.To the Moon has an incredible story, fantastic artwork, and an absolutely beautiful soundtrack. It evokes a variety of emotions, and contains plenty of comic relief. I would absolutely recommend To the Moon for any casual gamers, particularly those who love visual novels.

content:
y 9, 2016
												While this game is certainly not bad, it's not exactly good either. But since most reviews are positive anyway, I might aswell tell you why it just didn't work for me.-The storyIn it's core I thought the overall concept was actually pretty original. You pay as two scientist who travel back through a dying man's memories in order to grant him his last wish artificially: taking him to the moon (roll credits). Though during the story, your original objective is often questioned, as you begin to understand that this wish is not what would make your patient truly happy.So, it's really not the story that set me off, it's rather...-The dialogueYou'd think that in a story that's supposed to make you sad and teary, you wouldn't need a character for comic relief. But damnit, the second main character suplied you with a steady ammount of jokes in all the wrong places. I just couldn't take the game serious anymore. At the first half of the story, whenever there was an emotional moment, that same guy, messed it up over an over again. And by the time the game was starting to get deep, it was just too late for me. You see, the sad moments of the game largely depend on how you attached you grow to the characters over time. And maybe it's just me, but I hated both of them.-GameplayWell, interesting gameplay is virtually nonexistent. But that's really not an issue in a story driven game. As I mentioned before, it has a great outline, but it just feels so unrefined at some places that it just wasn't enjoyable for me.-The lengthYou'll probably finish the game in 3-4 hours. And while I don't want to badmouth the content, you may think that it's been a short ride if you don't even have all the trading cards by the time you are done.All in all, I'd say it's okay if you can pick it up during a sale. But I really don't think it's worth the full price if you take a look at what it offers. Just about 4 hours of gameplay which aren't even amazing. But I assume that most people have a far better time, given that they don't dislike the main characters as much as I do.

												The reason mainly why I recommend this game is because of the truly amazing and original storyline it has along with the character development regarding the introduced characters. This game (story) just never bores you. It has something that wants you to keep playing, something that wants you to explore more of the things that lay ahead of you. Humor, romance, adventure, puzzles and fantasy it has it all. Really worth the pocket money exchanged for the game. Not to mention the soundtracks. They are BEAUTIFUL. The soundtracks are just so overwhelming and so well placed in every scene, that you can't help to live with the characters. To have feels so deep that somehow your heart will bump against your chest painfully along with the pixelated tears that drop down your cheeks. It is unimaginable how much work was put into everything to create this splendid game of artwork, but what I can say is that this was truly one of the best games I've played on the Steam Community. To the RPG and Adventure lovers like me: surely try this out, especially if you're in for tearjerkers.

content:
er 28, 2016
												The music, which has been received very well as far as I've heard (pun!) since its release, alongside the storyline going along themes that people can relate to worldwide no matter the culture and age especially with the underlying themes of the game brings, for this reviewer, a connection or at least the prominent idea of the importance of many things everyone has in common in life--and the simplicity of experiencing existence, and memory.Personally, before playing this game amongst many other things, I felt cloistered and numb to most feelings (primarily due to depression), and coincidentally amongst many other things playing this (or at least listening to the music) helped quite a lot, and felt like breaking this 'shell' of being able to feel less, maybe because of the simplicity of its presentation or the humor [which may be different from person to person, as Dr. Watts can sometimes be a bit too silly], but all these add to the wholeness of detail in the game; lighthearted comic relief, and witty insight in turn. This game would be 'personal' too, on many levels with many people, as far as many reviews can note. Personally, I loved being able to feel--and personally, reflecting on the memory from all exposure within this game brought me to tears.Happy tears.Alongside touching experiences that are coming to society's eyes in recent note (Asperger's/Autism, etc), the game is also presents and showing its stuff rather than telling it all (given the dialogue and such) by letting you experience everything through the eyes of characters themselves, or at least those nearest to them to get their story.The Developers and their team are also very spirited and communicative folks! That's a major plus--including how they treat people, fan and otherwise alike.Would recommend this game fully--alongside recommending it for generations to come. The DLC (including the comic) are also worth the experience! (Wordless--picture only comic)E: My English may not be that good in writing this review! Apologies ahead!

content:
r 31, 2016
												I went into this game not expecting much out of it. It was cheap and I was bored. A lot of my friends had played it and said good things about it, and there's not much I can say in detail without spoiling, however, here are some criticisms and praises of the game.Criticism:The control scheme takes some getting used to, and you'll find yourself getting stuck on objects you didn't know you could. You can move by either clicking an area, or using the arrow keys on your computer (I didn't try playing with a controller or game pad). The game also tends to be a bit repetitive in gameplay, where you are continuously, until the end, doing the same thing over and over again to get more and more of the story. It's also a pixel art game, so if you're looking for amazing graphics, look elsewhere.Praise:The score for this game is absolutely amazing. I love all of the music from the game, and it is used to fit ambiance of the scenes very well. The game is very immersive in its story, where, if you take the time to care, you'll develop a bond with the characters as you traverse time. The overall story is absolutely amazing, and where the game lacks in overall gameplay, it makes up for in this story. If you're looking for an emotional, story oriented game to spend a couple hours on, this is definitely not a bad purchase. I'd most certainly recommend this game to anyone who wants a heavily story oriented game.

content:
r 31, 2016
												I went into this game not expecting much out of it. It was cheap and I was bored. A lot of my friends had played it and said good things about it, and there's not much I can say in detail without spoiling, however, here are some criticisms and praises of the game.Criticism:The control scheme takes some getting used to, and you'll find yourself getting stuck on objects you didn't know you could. You can move by either clicking an area, or using the arrow keys on your computer (I didn't try playing with a controller or game pad). The game also tends to be a bit repetitive in gameplay, where you are continuously, until the end, doing the same thing over and over again to get more and more of the story. It's also a pixel art game, so if you're looking for amazing graphics, look elsewhere.Praise:The score for this game is absolutely amazing. I love all of the music from the game, and it is used to fit ambiance of the scenes very well. The game is very immersive in its story, where, if you take the time to care, you'll develop a bond with the characters as you traverse time. The overall story is absolutely amazing, and where the game lacks in overall gameplay, it makes up for in this story. If you're looking for an emotional, story oriented game to spend a couple hours on, this is definitely not a bad purchase. I'd most certainly recommend this game to anyone who wants a heavily story oriented game.

 This will hit you right in the feels....and you'll be glad it did. Don't be put off by the way this game starts, I was, and I beg you to learn from my mistake.After playing through the first 10 minutes or so i quickly declared the game to be "boring as hell" and "A magnificent waste of my time", but when I stumbled upon it in my library again late yesterday evening I gave it another shot....and played straight through the night just so I would get to finish it, hell I even played the minisodes while I was at it.I would highly recommend this game to anyone, it might not give you that adrenaline rush some people crave but it will sure as hell kick you right in the feels, and you'll thank it for doing so. During this game I laughed, I cried, and most of all I just had a ton of fun. The graphis aren't great, and yeah, sometimes the controls are a little wonky, but the AMAZING soundtrack won't leave you any time or need to worry about that. From some of the very first scenes to the very end, the music grabbed me and pulled me straight through the just as well written story. I would honestly tell everyone to buy this game, take a day off, and just play through it in one sitting. At the end, you'll almost be a different person. This game tells a wonderfull story, and does so in such a way that no matter what you wanted to happen, what you expected, what you hated, what you liked, you'll still love it, just the way it was.This game definitely got itself a place in my heart, and I hope it'll find it's way to your heart too.

content:
r 18, 2015
												Great story with terrible graphics (game runs on a stupidly small resolution with no options to change that). The gameplay mostly consists of walking around, clicking on things and reading the dialogue. But the writing is excellent. The story is about a dying man whose last wish is to go to the moon. You play as the employees of a corporation that is capable of altering people's memories to give them the illusion of having a different life thus fulfilling their last wish before they die. The narrative unfolds in a reverse chronological order as you go back in time through the old man's memories, learning about his life and finding a way to make his wish come true. It's an interesting way to tell a story and it's executed quite well here.

content:
er 28, 2016
												I've been meaning to get this game for a long time. Now I finally had a chance to actually play it, and I must say I regretted not getting it sooner. There was not a single thing I did not like about To The Moon. The story is well-written, the soundtrack is simply amazing, and the art is fitting. The mechanics could have been better but nothing that's stopping me from thoroughly enjoying the game.John's dying wish is to go to the moon, and the doctors, Eva and Niel, are contracted to fulfill it. To do it, they need to dive into John's memory to find out the cause of that desire. The story uncovers as you gradually dig deeper into John's past one stage at a time. This is a nice reminder that story progression doesn't necessarily means going forward.The puzzle pieces start to fit together as you go, and you get to know more about the characters, all of which are likeable in their own ways. Although, I find it funny that while the story is supposed to revolve around John, I feel like River is the most developed character throughout the story. I slowly started to understand why she acted the way she did, what she really wanted, how her mind worked, and I felt more sympathetic towards her than any other character. But while it's all dramatic and emotional, it is balanced by the constant comic relief mostly by the dialogue exchanges between Eva and Niel.The art isn't at all remarkable but it complements the atmosphere of the story very well and I probably won't have it any other way. Despite the rather low quality, they make up for it by using appropriate visual effects and color schemes. Even the subtle sprite movements, such as the eyes and arms, can show you what the characters are thinking or feeling during certain events. The soundtrack is, like I mentioned earlier, simply amazing. Even the simple piano piece that John wrote for River was very soothing and fun to listen to.Overall, I really enjoyed playing this game and I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a game with good story.

content:
, 2015
												'To the Moon' is a reminder that first impressions can be misleading. When I began playing, I found myself wondering whether I had picked up an amateur title. The dialogue and interface are a bit sloppy, and it takes some trial and error to figure out the controls. However, overlook these aspects and a well-paced, suspenseful story begins to unfold over instalments. To my surprise, I concluded this interactive story with personal reflections, deep thoughts and a sense of appreciation.Additional notes:- With a Logitech controller, there were some issues. At one point in the game, the player is required to walk across logs in order to proceed with the story. I got stuck behind a log, which rendered the entire 'level' unplayable. I ended up walking up the side of a lighthouse, off cliffs and then eventually entered the sky. I was forced to reload my save several times. Eventually I discovered that for this particular section of the game, it is better to resort to the keyboard controls instead.- Nice music, but somewhat repetitive in nature.

content:
r 14, 2014
												I honesty didn't know what this game was about. From one of the screen shots in the store page I somehow expected a RPG. It is not.Gameplay-wise this "game" does not have a lot to offer. You collect items through some restricted areas, resolve a puzzle and jump to the next area. It's not the game's strong suit. This is not about gaming, not in the most literal sense anyway. This "game" is all about its story. It plays like an interactive movie.Like many have said before me, it would spoil the whole thing to go into details on why the story is so poignant. And it's also hard to put into words. Think “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind”.It is true that this game is all about experience, because, well, it’s about navigating through one person’s history, memories, emotions. The more you dig into that life, the more you uncover some truths. Some feel very wrong, other absolutely great, but the whole process never ceases to feel incredibly intrusive.This is one of those story where you’re not sure where it’s headed before being close to the end. You don’t really know why that specific objective has been set (having a dying old man go to the moon), you just know you have to get there.If I were to explain what happens during the big reveal, I would probably make it sound cheesy. But not this game. The execution is great and unravels the missing pieces at the perfect moment. (I’m thinking about the star-gazing scene, for those who are wondering, not the... hum... reverse-engine one)Once you have reached that point, the rest of the story was pretty much predictable in my opinion, but I still enjoyed it very much. I put on my cry baby suit and didn't stop until the end, or rather 10 minutes after I closed the game.The conclusion both feels utterly wrong and completely right, and is endearingly beautiful.You know these movies/books/games/songs that leave you bewildered, happy and sad at the same time? And the feeling lingers on for the rest of day? This is one of them: it has one of the most heartfelt stories I have experienced, up there with the movie I mentioned earlier, Shadow of the Colossus and the likes.♥♥♥♥ing play this game.

content:
6, 2014
												This isn't my typical game. Between stealth games, first-person shooters and action RPGs, I don't frequently delve into the "interactive story" game genre. I was almost embarassed to put the game on my wishlist, given how cheesy and pretentious the trailer looked.With that out of the way, I have to say that To The Moon does its job really well. The premise is interesting and the execution is even better, with a strong plot throughout that feels unique. The characters are especially well-written. Some have complained about Dr. Watts disrupting the feels, but I enjoyed his humor and I think he kept the game from becoming too full of itself. (Whenever I thought something was cheesy or pretentious, Watts was there to back me up). The later parts of the game were mind-blowing and very emotional. The story is great!The graphics look old and "nostalgic" (which actually ties into the story, if you think hard enough), but are still quite detailed and very pretty backdrops for the key story moments. The soundtrack repeats itself a lot, but is still very good and always fits well with what is currently happening in-game. Actual "gameplay" is mostly minimal, but there are several special sequences where gameplay is used effectively to convey emotion. Every part of the game strengthens the story in a big way.9/10Wear a helmet

												"This game made me cry. It was a good cry. It made me think about my dad and how much he loved me (probably due to his love for the space program). This connection had less to do with the game’s story, and more to do with the design: to provide a heart-rich story that reminds people of what’s important – life, family, and sacrifices for the ones you love."River’s story fascinates me because the story of people with Asperger’s Syndrome rarely gets told. To my knowledge, this is the first time this has happened in a videogame. River isn’t the only socially marginalized character to have her tale shared with the world in a videogame. Score: 95/100To call this "a game" would be (with the current state of gaming industry) an insult towards this piece of art.Most people who played the game loved it (and so did I). Some complain about the writing and I'd say there were some "weaker" parts where the dialogues could seem a lil' bit shallow, but the story itself compensates for any mistakes the developers might have done.There's nothing much more I can say without spoiling the story. content:
er 19, 2016
												An absolutely beautiful story, delivered in a pace slow enough to let you contemplate every moment, but still making you play a second time to fully comprehend all the little details. Clearly, this game has been crafted with plenty of passion and experience.The very introduction reflects the entire game's mood perfectly. The protagonists are having delightful interactions, eventhough they drove over an animal and had a car accident.  Throughout the entire game, you will experience this contrast of cheerful colours, bright music and lighthearted dialogue against cruel reality, shocking revelations and gruesome secrets.As for the story itself, the characters are all congenial in some aspect. There are no uninteresting interactions and no unexplained plot conveniences. Besides some joke content not relevant to the story (instead to brighten the mood), there are no plot holes or unnecessary story elements. Everything of the actual story makes sense in the end, but a few questions about the frame story remain unanswered, probably to be expanded on in the next "episodes".If you like story-driven games and don't mind the pixelated graphics, you should definitely consider playing this game!
